text: <@U0GN0A9EV> <@U0B9N0HF0> this is totally not groomed for client eyes (it has words like suck and fucking), but this is my repository of thoughts, inspo, and sketches that we discussed. shout with questions! <https://docs.google.com/a/uncorkedstudios.com/presentation/d/1oWiILulNeB_S21p50gVxNEk9BIr5rAWjo15zIjuGFWw/edit?usp=sharing>

<@U0HPGQ4KH> those are great. No, I think the visual output is still in? As Sarah mentions in her deck above, it's gamification, but w/o the leaderboards, badges, etc. that make up other gamification experiences. It's accountability to your tribe. Btw Thanks <@U1172PRDX>!

i think the visual output is great. it gives me a reason to continue contributing to my overall composition. and if i can get a pair of shoes to commemorate a snapshot in my fitness journey, that’s a wonderful memory!

_State of Play used unusual tools to bring the game to life. Concept art was initially done by splatting Indian ink onto watercolour paper, and an iPad Pro was extensively during production. Firstly for concept art and then for level design, using ProCreate and the Apple pencil. Game designer Steffan Glynn would transfer these to Unity to work up into levels to test, and return to the drawing board to refine them.and figure out the fascinating mechanisms that power this unique world._
